PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of our questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events; if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaires.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneers in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

1. Your full name: George Stephens

2. Your address: 518 Balfour Rd., Melfort, Saskatchewan

3. Date: March 26, 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Joseph County, Ontario, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Joseph Stephens

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April, 1889

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you could not read when you came). I am 84 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). I suppose my parents learned about the west through the above sources.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   I traveled with my father's brother, two brothers and two sisters.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   T.P.R. to Winnipeg

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   I do not remember much of what happened during this period.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   We went to my father's homestead, which he had bought on 1st January 1883.

16. Where did you settle and take up land?
   I purchased land near the above location.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   I lived in the above district until 1953 when my boys and I moved to our present address.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   My parents did some farming and my father worked in lumber camps during winter months.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   I traveled with my sisters, mother, two brothers.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   I do not remember much of what happened during this period.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   We lived at Village La Prairie for a short time before settling near Regina City in 1878.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   We went to my father's homestead, which he had lived on, 1st Summer 1893.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   I purchased land later near the above location.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   I lived in the above district until 1953 when my boys and I moved to our present address.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   My parents did some farming and my father worked in lumber camps during winter months.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Answered in Stirling, 18.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

We were somewhat worried during the North-West Rebellion in 1885, as with our guide a number of them in our district said they would go to Lethbridge who were to settle in the Kinsella Branch of the CPR through their district in 1914 was important also the Regina Branch of the CPR in 1918.

25. When was the first car used in the community?
   1910 or 1911

26. If you owned a car before 1914, then did you buy it? What makes?
    In 1913 it was a Paterson.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
    You'd Uppelle, 11 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
    After the railway came our trading center was Boissevain. Then years later we all had cars in Winkler and Winnipeg, however in Boissevain.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
    Usually weekly.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
    1904

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?
    What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any charges in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period?

Somewhere around 1906.

We do mostly our buying locally.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
    In 1910 Balcarney South Rural Telephone Co., Ltd.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of starting permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   1910 or 1911

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes?
   In 1913 it was a Paterson.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Your "Upfield" 11 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   After the railway came our trading area was Balcarres. Years later we all had cars in Edmonton and Winnipeg.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Usually weekly.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   1904

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?
   What kind of articles did you buy by mail order? Did they also list any changes in their proposition of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period?

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   In 1910 Balcarres South Rural Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons did they have for moving?

Several of our people moved away from here.

Green fields, are you there, away?

35. Did any people move away during the period 1917-1920?

No.

36. If you or some members of your family have held public offices, or have been engaged in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I helped to organize the first school district in 1918 and was a member of the Board of Education from 1918 to 1920.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were listed to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

In the district, I have been a member of the Board of Education since 1918.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)

They were named after the people who lived there.

39. Did any changes in names occur? Give facts of such changes.

Yes, the school district was first called "Brownfield No. 4," after Mr. Brownfield, one of the first settlers.

40. Did any buildings exist before 1884?

Yes, the old schoolhouse, called "Old School," and the old school district office.

41. Did any changes occur in the district during this time?

Yes, the old schoolhouse was replaced by a new one.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? If so, where did they go?

Several of our people moved away from here in 1914.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes

36. If you or some members of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

I helped to organize the local school district in 1910 and was elected to the Board of Education in 1912.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were willing to have or do something in the district, mention it here, listing dates whenever possible (such as voting the first election, etc.).

In 1912, I voted in the first election.

38. How old are the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)

Give: (1) name and corporation of person suggesting place name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption.

Since the first name was given, date and reason for change.

Our school district was first called "Bowmanville No. 3."
